learning_outcomes.description: Critically appraise the evidence underpinning practices used to support student engagement, behaviour, connectedness, and wellbeing and establish and sustain safe and supportive learning environments.
Identify and apply evidence informed approaches specifically aimed at providing multi-tiered systems of support that include social, emotional, and behavioural supports for students.
Design safe and supportive learning environments for school students and apply approaches that teach and reinforce desired classroom behaviours.
Analyse the relationship between function of behaviour and environment, including cultural and contextual factors.
Synthesise research to explore links between student behaviour and wellbeing, and engagement and learning.
Investigate practices that can prevent student disengagement and develop plans for students who are exhibiting behaviours of concern.
Critically reflect on implications for promoting positive student wellbeing and behaviour in professional practice and productive relationships with students, families, and communities.

assessments.task_description:
This is a multi-part task. A weekly quiz will be given to students during the tutorials specified in this task description (Weeks 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 11, 13).

The 10 quizzes will focus on assessing and implementing MTSS evidence-informed, proactive, Tier 1 teaching practices and skills at a whole-school and classroom level
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: Students who fail to attend a tutorial in which a quiz is administered will receive no mark for that week. However, a session will be provided at the end of semester during teaching weeks where students will be provided with a supplementary quiz for each week missed.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Select from a scenario that describes a learner who might be vulnerable in a classroom and use high-quality, proactive, evidence-based teaching practices and approaches (including culturally responsive strategies) to design an action plan to increase student engagement/connectedness, prevent behaviours of concern and/or disengagement, and address the wellbeing needs of both the student and the teacher. The plan should include strategies and preplanned responses for building positive relationships with the student and their family.

APST 1.1, 1.3, 1.4, 3.7, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4, 7.3
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission instructions are outlined on UQ Learn (Blackboard).
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Select from a case study (provided on UQ Learn) and write a multi-tiered plan to enhance student engagement and support student behaviour. Include within the plan strategies to prevent behaviours of concern, and to teach and reinforce desired behaviours. 

APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission instructions are outlined on UQ Learn (Blackboard).
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1

Preplan and rehearse responses such as positive greetings at the door, creating predictability through routines (APST 1.3, 1.5, 3.3, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2).


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1 Preplan and rehearse responses such as positive greetings at the door, creating predictability through routines (APST 1.3, 1.5, 3.3, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1

An overview of the current policies, whole-school behaviour frameworks and practices that are promoted to create and sustain Positive Learning Environments and create high expectations to reinforce learning habits for students (APST 4.4, 7.1, 7.2).

In this lecture, preservice teachers are introduced to policies and whole-school behaviour frameworks, such as Positive Behaviour Support (Center on PBIS, 2025; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; Keller-Bell & Short, 2019; Mallory et al., 2022: McDaniel et al., 2015; McKay-Brown & Tutton, 2022; Missouri School-Wide Positive Behavior Support, 2025; Mitchell et al., 2018; Poed & de Bruin, 2022; Schminke et al., 2022; Sargeant, 2020; Simonsen & Myers, 2015; Stormont, 2012; Whitefield et al., 2022) as foundational tools for creating safe and supportive learning environments. They will explore how teachers engage with these whole school behaviour frameworks. They explore the research evidence showing the impact of building positive relationships on student behaviours and outcomes (AERO, 2023, 2025; Coe et al., 2020; Conway & Foggett, 2021; Cook et al., 2018; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; McDonald, 2019; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018; Poed et al., 2020; Scott et al., 2017; World Bank Group, 2022). They are also introduced to the research evidence showing the importance of holding high expectations for all learners and developing clear and well-defined rules and routines to establish clear expectations for learning habits and encourage smooth transitions to maximise learning time (Boushey & Behne, 2024; Leung, 2022) (Core Content 3.1.1, 3.1.3, 3.2.1, 3.5.1).


Learning outcomes: L01, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1 An overview of the current policies, whole-school behaviour frameworks and practices that are promoted to create and sustain Positive Learning Environments and create high expectations to reinforce learning habits for students (APST 4.4, 7.1, 7.2). In this lecture, preservice teachers are introduced to policies and whole-school behaviour frameworks, such as Positive Behaviour Support (Center on PBIS, 2025; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; Keller-Bell & Short, 2019; Mallory et al., 2022: McDaniel et al., 2015; McKay-Brown & Tutton, 2022; Missouri School-Wide Positive Behavior Support, 2025; Mitchell et al., 2018; Poed & de Bruin, 2022; Schminke et al., 2022; Sargeant, 2020; Simonsen & Myers, 2015; Stormont, 2012; Whitefield et al., 2022) as foundational tools for creating safe and supportive learning environments. They will explore how teachers engage with these whole school behaviour frameworks. They explore the research evidence showing the impact of building positive relationships on student behaviours and outcomes (AERO, 2023, 2025; Coe et al., 2020; Conway & Foggett, 2021; Cook et al., 2018; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; McDonald, 2019; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018; Poed et al., 2020; Scott et al., 2017; World Bank Group, 2022). They are also introduced to the research evidence showing the importance of holding high expectations for all learners and developing clear and well-defined rules and routines to establish clear expectations for learning habits and encourage smooth transitions to maximise learning time (Boushey & Behne, 2024; Leung, 2022) (Core Content 3.1.1, 3.1.3, 3.2.1, 3.5.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2

Establishing and explicitly teaching classroom rules/expectations and routines to provide a structured, safe, and positive classroom environment as part of a whole-school behaviour framework (APST 1.6, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2) (Core Content 3.1).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2 Establishing and explicitly teaching classroom rules/expectations and routines to provide a structured, safe, and positive classroom environment as part of a whole-school behaviour framework (APST 1.6, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2) (Core Content 3.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2

Fundamental elements and underpinning theory of a Multi-Tiered System of Support and why it is effective (APST 1.6, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4).

In this lecture, preservice teachers learn about the fundamental elements and underpinning theory of another whole-school behaviour framework known as multi-tiered system of support (MTSS) and how teachers currently engage with this framework. They explore why MTSS is effective in addressing the diverse needs of students and promoting positive learning environments by providing varying levels of support (Core Content 2.6.1, 3.5.1)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2 Fundamental elements and underpinning theory of a Multi-Tiered System of Support and why it is effective (APST 1.6, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4). In this lecture, preservice teachers learn about the fundamental elements and underpinning theory of another whole-school behaviour framework known as multi-tiered system of support (MTSS) and how teachers currently engage with this framework. They explore why MTSS is effective in addressing the diverse needs of students and promoting positive learning environments by providing varying levels of support (Core Content 2.6.1, 3.5.1)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3

Active supervision, waiting and scanning (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.1).

Learning outcomes: L01, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3 Active supervision, waiting and scanning (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3

How a multi-tiered system of support works at a whole school level, including culturally responsive Tier 1 practices (APST 1.1, 1.4, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4).

This lecture focuses on implementing Tier 1 practices within an MTSS framework at the whole-school level. Preservice teachers also learn about elements that would apply to the classroom level, such as explicitly teaching behavioural expectations in the classroom and identifying predictable classroom behaviours. They also explore expectations for staff behaviour such as being on time and organised for class, preplan and rehearse responses such as communicating and collaborating respectfully with students and their families, and teaching and modelling fairness and inclusivity. They learn about creating systems that are informed by a functional understanding of student behaviour (Alberto & Troutman, 2021; Dunlap et al., 2018; O’Neill et al., 2014). (Core Content 2.6.2, 3.1.3, 3.4.2, 3.4.3, 3.5.1).

Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3 How a multi-tiered system of support works at a whole school level, including culturally responsive Tier 1 practices (APST 1.1, 1.4, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4). This lecture focuses on implementing Tier 1 practices within an MTSS framework at the whole-school level. Preservice teachers also learn about elements that would apply to the classroom level, such as explicitly teaching behavioural expectations in the classroom and identifying predictable classroom behaviours. They also explore expectations for staff behaviour such as being on time and organised for class, preplan and rehearse responses such as communicating and collaborating respectfully with students and their families, and teaching and modelling fairness and inclusivity. They learn about creating systems that are informed by a functional understanding of student behaviour (Alberto & Troutman, 2021; Dunlap et al., 2018; O’Neill et al., 2014). (Core Content 2.6.2, 3.1.3, 3.4.2, 3.4.3, 3.5.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4

Preplan and rehearse responses such as call to attention, giving instructions (APST 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.1.)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4 Preplan and rehearse responses such as call to attention, giving instructions (APST 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.1.)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4

How a multi-tiered system of support works at a classroom level, including culturally responsive Tier 1 effective teaching practices and high-quality instruction (APST 11, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4).

Preservice teachers learn about the research that supports implementing Tier 1 practices within an MTSS framework at the classroom level. They focus on explicitly teaching classroom expectations, creating predictability, active supervision, giving simple instructions and prompts, opportunities to respond through a range of questioning techniques, cueing with parallel acknowledgement. Preservice teachers also learn the research evidence showing the impact of high quality instruction as a protective measure, and the research showing the relationship between effective pedagogy and increased positive behaviour (including why specific practices are particularly effective in preventing undesired behaviour), with particular emphases on: classroom setup and organisation (Coe et al., 2020; Cook et al., 2028; Meuser et al., 2022; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018). They will learn how to preplan and rehearse responses such as explicit instruction and opportunities to respond (AERO, 2023, 2025; Barile, 2020; Boushey & Behne, 2024; Coe et al., 2020; Education Endowment Foundation, 2021; Education Queensland, 2007; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Leung, 2022; Menzies et al., 2017), learning activities (individual and group), specific examples of rules and routines such as structuring lessons and tasks to follow the gradual release of responsibility, do-nows, dealing with lesson downtime and transitions, exit slips/lesson reflections (Fisher & Frey, 2021; Marzano, 2012; Scott et al., 2017), dealing with external disruptions (Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Porta & Hudson, 2025), providing behaviour specific praise, body language encouraging, behavioural momentum (Coe et al., 2020; Conway & Foggett, 2020; Education Endowment Foundation, 2021; Royer et al., 2018), incorporating choice (Institute of Education Sciences, 2025), selective attending, redirection to learning, applying consequences, and unconditional positive regard (Coe et al., 2020; Education Queensland, 2007; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Poed et al., 2020) (Core Content 2.6.2, 2.6.3, 3.1.4, 3.2.2, 3.2.3, 3.3.3, 3.4.3, 3.5.1).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4 How a multi-tiered system of support works at a classroom level, including culturally responsive Tier 1 effective teaching practices and high-quality instruction (APST 11, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4). Preservice teachers learn about the research that supports implementing Tier 1 practices within an MTSS framework at the classroom level. They focus on explicitly teaching classroom expectations, creating predictability, active supervision, giving simple instructions and prompts, opportunities to respond through a range of questioning techniques, cueing with parallel acknowledgement. Preservice teachers also learn the research evidence showing the impact of high quality instruction as a protective measure, and the research showing the relationship between effective pedagogy and increased positive behaviour (including why specific practices are particularly effective in preventing undesired behaviour), with particular emphases on: classroom setup and organisation (Coe et al., 2020; Cook et al., 2028; Meuser et al., 2022; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018). They will learn how to preplan and rehearse responses such as explicit instruction and opportunities to respond (AERO, 2023, 2025; Barile, 2020; Boushey & Behne, 2024; Coe et al., 2020; Education Endowment Foundation, 2021; Education Queensland, 2007; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Leung, 2022; Menzies et al., 2017), learning activities (individual and group), specific examples of rules and routines such as structuring lessons and tasks to follow the gradual release of responsibility, do-nows, dealing with lesson downtime and transitions, exit slips/lesson reflections (Fisher & Frey, 2021; Marzano, 2012; Scott et al., 2017), dealing with external disruptions (Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Porta & Hudson, 2025), providing behaviour specific praise, body language encouraging, behavioural momentum (Coe et al., 2020; Conway & Foggett, 2020; Education Endowment Foundation, 2021; Royer et al., 2018), incorporating choice (Institute of Education Sciences, 2025), selective attending, redirection to learning, applying consequences, and unconditional positive regard (Coe et al., 2020; Education Queensland, 2007; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Poed et al., 2020) (Core Content 2.6.2, 2.6.3, 3.1.4, 3.2.2, 3.2.3, 3.3.3, 3.4.3, 3.5.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5

Preplan and rehearse responses such as behaviour specific praise/feedback and cueing with parallel acknowledgement as part of a whole-school behaviour framework (APST 3.3, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.4).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5 Preplan and rehearse responses such as behaviour specific praise/feedback and cueing with parallel acknowledgement as part of a whole-school behaviour framework (APST 3.3, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.4).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5

Student & Teacher wellbeing (APST 3.5, 4.1).

In this lecture, preservice teachers learn that higher levels of personal wellbeing are more likely to contribute to their use of innovative and engaging teaching techniques, which lead to better student interaction and learning, better student-teacher relationships, and foster a positive classroom environment (Brunzell et al., 2021; Cárdenas et al., 2022; Eyre, 2016; Falecki & Mann, 2022; Fox et al., 2023; Hascher & Waber, 2021; McNeven et al., 2023; Shay et al., 2021; Student Wellbeing Hub, 2020). They also learn that students with optimal social and emotional wellbeing exhibit fewer behaviours of concern leading to classroom environments conducive to learning, higher motivation, and better academic outcomes. They explore whole-school approaches to social-emotional learning (Core Content 3.3.2, 3.5.1).

Learning outcomes: L01, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5 Student & Teacher wellbeing (APST 3.5, 4.1). In this lecture, preservice teachers learn that higher levels of personal wellbeing are more likely to contribute to their use of innovative and engaging teaching techniques, which lead to better student interaction and learning, better student-teacher relationships, and foster a positive classroom environment (Brunzell et al., 2021; Cárdenas et al., 2022; Eyre, 2016; Falecki & Mann, 2022; Fox et al., 2023; Hascher & Waber, 2021; McNeven et al., 2023; Shay et al., 2021; Student Wellbeing Hub, 2020). They also learn that students with optimal social and emotional wellbeing exhibit fewer behaviours of concern leading to classroom environments conducive to learning, higher motivation, and better academic outcomes. They explore whole-school approaches to social-emotional learning (Core Content 3.3.2, 3.5.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6

Behaviour modelling (APST 3.3, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.2).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6 Behaviour modelling (APST 3.3, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.2).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6

Student engagement and connectedness and the relationship to motivation (APST, 3.5, 4.1, 4.3).

In this lecture, preservice teachers explore explicit behavioural expectations and how these can be made culturally responsive so that all students can be held to high expectations for their behaviour (AERO, 2022; Education Queensland, 2007; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Naylor et al., 2022; Schminke et al., 2022; Shay & Miller, 2021; Vass, 2017; Whitefield et al., 2022). We explore the literature on student engagement/disengagement, strategies for enhancing student engagement, research on building positive relationships with students and families through creating belonging and connectedness (AERO, 2023, 2025; Coe et al., 2020; Conway & Foggett, 2021; Cook et al., 2018; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; McDonald, 2019; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018; Poed et al., 2020; Scott et al., 2017; World Bank Group, 2022) (full references listed at end of table) (Core Content 3.2.1).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6 Student engagement and connectedness and the relationship to motivation (APST, 3.5, 4.1, 4.3). In this lecture, preservice teachers explore explicit behavioural expectations and how these can be made culturally responsive so that all students can be held to high expectations for their behaviour (AERO, 2022; Education Queensland, 2007; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Naylor et al., 2022; Schminke et al., 2022; Shay & Miller, 2021; Vass, 2017; Whitefield et al., 2022). We explore the literature on student engagement/disengagement, strategies for enhancing student engagement, research on building positive relationships with students and families through creating belonging and connectedness (AERO, 2023, 2025; Coe et al., 2020; Conway & Foggett, 2021; Cook et al., 2018; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; McDonald, 2019; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018; Poed et al., 2020; Scott et al., 2017; World Bank Group, 2022) (full references listed at end of table) (Core Content 3.2.1).

learning_activities.topic: Mid-Semester Break
learning_activities.topic_description: Mid-Semester Break

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7

Setting high expectations and opportunities to respond (APST 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2) (Core Content 3.2, 3,3).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7 Setting high expectations and opportunities to respond (APST 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2) (Core Content 3.2, 3,3).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7

Culturally responsive practices, including rules and routines, to develop respectful relationships with students, parents, and communities (APST 1.3, 1.4, 3.5, 3.7, 4.1, 7.1, 7.3, 7.4).

In this lecture, preservice teachers examine how rules and routines can be co-created with students and families to ensure they are culturally responsive and foster a safe, respectful and supportive learning environment. We also explore the research on how to build student and family engagement through co-creating a climate of trust (AERO, 2023, 2025; Coe et al., 2020; Conway & Foggett, 2021; Cook et al., 2018; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; McDonald, 2019; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018; Poed et al., 2020; Scott et al., 2017; World Bank Group, 2022) (Core Content 3.1.2, 3.3.3, 3.4.2).

Learning outcomes: L04, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7 Culturally responsive practices, including rules and routines, to develop respectful relationships with students, parents, and communities (APST 1.3, 1.4, 3.5, 3.7, 4.1, 7.1, 7.3, 7.4). In this lecture, preservice teachers examine how rules and routines can be co-created with students and families to ensure they are culturally responsive and foster a safe, respectful and supportive learning environment. We also explore the research on how to build student and family engagement through co-creating a climate of trust (AERO, 2023, 2025; Coe et al., 2020; Conway & Foggett, 2021; Cook et al., 2018; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; McDonald, 2019; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018; Poed et al., 2020; Scott et al., 2017; World Bank Group, 2022) (Core Content 3.1.2, 3.3.3, 3.4.2).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8

Preplan and rehearse responses such as selective attending, redirecting to learning (APST 3.3, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.1).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8 Preplan and rehearse responses such as selective attending, redirecting to learning (APST 3.3, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8

Functional understanding of student behaviour (APST 3.5, 4.3, 4.4, 5.1).

In this lecture, preservice teachers learn about functional thinking about behaviour, a fundamental concept underpinning the Positive Behaviour Support whole school framework. They learn how to identify the reasons underpinning a student behaviour and how to collect and analyse data on student behaviour, triggers, and functions to inform strategies to support the student (Core Content 3.5.1).

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8 Functional understanding of student behaviour (APST 3.5, 4.3, 4.4, 5.1). In this lecture, preservice teachers learn about functional thinking about behaviour, a fundamental concept underpinning the Positive Behaviour Support whole school framework. They learn how to identify the reasons underpinning a student behaviour and how to collect and analyse data on student behaviour, triggers, and functions to inform strategies to support the student (Core Content 3.5.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9

Giving choices, adjustments for early finishers (APST 1.1, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.2).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9 Giving choices, adjustments for early finishers (APST 1.1, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.2).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9

How to prevent behaviours of concern and teach and reinforce desired behaviours through specific and positive feedback (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4).

In this lecture, preservice teachers learn to identify behaviours of concern, understanding triggers and underlying causes, how to minimise their occurrence through environmental modifications, structured routines, preplan and rehearse responses such as prompts and precorrections, how to teach desired behaviours, and provide specific and positive feedback to reinforce these behaviours through a range of reinforcement techniques (AERO, 2023, 2025; Boushey & Behne, 2024; Coe et al., 2020; Education Endowment Foundation, 2021; Education Queensland, 2007; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Leung, 2022; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018; Royer et al., 2018) (Core Content 3.1.3, 3.2.3, 3.4.3).

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9 How to prevent behaviours of concern and teach and reinforce desired behaviours through specific and positive feedback (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4). In this lecture, preservice teachers learn to identify behaviours of concern, understanding triggers and underlying causes, how to minimise their occurrence through environmental modifications, structured routines, preplan and rehearse responses such as prompts and precorrections, how to teach desired behaviours, and provide specific and positive feedback to reinforce these behaviours through a range of reinforcement techniques (AERO, 2023, 2025; Boushey & Behne, 2024; Coe et al., 2020; Education Endowment Foundation, 2021; Education Queensland, 2007; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Leung, 2022; Muijs & Reynolds, 2018; Royer et al., 2018) (Core Content 3.1.3, 3.2.3, 3.4.3).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10

Materials for this week will be online. There will be no face-to-face tutorials due to the Public Holiday.

Goal-setting and Tier 2 supports for targeted learners (APST 1.1, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10 Materials for this week will be online. There will be no face-to-face tutorials due to the Public Holiday. Goal-setting and Tier 2 supports for targeted learners (APST 1.1, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10

Materials for this week will be online. There will be no face-to-face lecture due to the Public Holiday.

Goal setting and targeted approaches to re-engage learners (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4).

In this lecture, preservice teachers learn about the importance of goals in motivation and engagement, characteristic of effective (SMART) goals, how to collaborate to set goals for targeted groups of students, and how to provide targeted supports for groups of learners who share similar reasons for disengagement or share similar behaviours of concern. We also discuss how to track progress and provide feedback/ reinforcement against goals, and strategies to use when goals aren’t being achieved (Core Content 3.3.1)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10 Materials for this week will be online. There will be no face-to-face lecture due to the Public Holiday. Goal setting and targeted approaches to re-engage learners (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4). In this lecture, preservice teachers learn about the importance of goals in motivation and engagement, characteristic of effective (SMART) goals, how to collaborate to set goals for targeted groups of students, and how to provide targeted supports for groups of learners who share similar reasons for disengagement or share similar behaviours of concern. We also discuss how to track progress and provide feedback/ reinforcement against goals, and strategies to use when goals aren’t being achieved (Core Content 3.3.1)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11

Preplan and rehearse responses such as providing consequences and calm, consistent and proportional responses to behaviour as part of a whole-school behaviour framework (APST 1.1, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.4).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11 Preplan and rehearse responses such as providing consequences and calm, consistent and proportional responses to behaviour as part of a whole-school behaviour framework (APST 1.1, 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3) (Core Content 3.4).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11

Maintaining expectations and teaching self-accountability and understanding of consequences (APST 1.1, 4.3, 4.4).

In this lecture, preservice teachers learn about the research evidence showing the importance of clear, consistent expectations, techniques for communicating and reinforcing these clearly, and how they can help shape student behaviour (AERO, 2022; Education Queensland, 2007; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Whitefield et al., 2022). They learn strategies for fostering self-accountability in students. They learn how to preplan and rehearse responses such as how to calmly and consistently respond to student behaviour using proportionate responses. They will be introduced to a whole school approach known as Restorative Practices. They learn the difference between natural and logical consequences, how consequences influence behaviour and how to address challenges related to functions reinforced by consequences (Core Content 3.2.1, 3.4.1, 3.4.2, 3.4.3, 3.5.1).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11 Maintaining expectations and teaching self-accountability and understanding of consequences (APST 1.1, 4.3, 4.4). In this lecture, preservice teachers learn about the research evidence showing the importance of clear, consistent expectations, techniques for communicating and reinforcing these clearly, and how they can help shape student behaviour (AERO, 2022; Education Queensland, 2007; Hepburn & Telfer, 2022; Institute of Education Sciences, 2025; Whitefield et al., 2022). They learn strategies for fostering self-accountability in students. They learn how to preplan and rehearse responses such as how to calmly and consistently respond to student behaviour using proportionate responses. They will be introduced to a whole school approach known as Restorative Practices. They learn the difference between natural and logical consequences, how consequences influence behaviour and how to address challenges related to functions reinforced by consequences (Core Content 3.2.1, 3.4.1, 3.4.2, 3.4.3, 3.5.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12

Goal-setting and Tier 3 supports for individual learners (APST 1.1, 3.7, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 7.3).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 12 Goal-setting and Tier 3 supports for individual learners (APST 1.1, 3.7, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4, 7.3).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12

Goal setting and intensive approaches to re-engage learners (APST 3.5, 3.7, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4, 7.3).

Building from the previous week, in this lecture, preservice teachers learn about how to collaborate to set goals for individual students through a wraparound model, and how to provide intensive supports for individual learners for whom the Tier 1 universal and Tier 2 targeted supports have been ineffective or insufficient. We also discuss how to track progress and provide feedback/reinforcement against individual goals informed by functional assessments and individual behaviour or safety plans (Core Content 3.3.1).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 12 Goal setting and intensive approaches to re-engage learners (APST 3.5, 3.7, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4, 7.3). Building from the previous week, in this lecture, preservice teachers learn about how to collaborate to set goals for individual students through a wraparound model, and how to provide intensive supports for individual learners for whom the Tier 1 universal and Tier 2 targeted supports have been ineffective or insufficient. We also discuss how to track progress and provide feedback/reinforcement against individual goals informed by functional assessments and individual behaviour or safety plans (Core Content 3.3.1).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13

Preplan and rehearse responses such as de-escalation as part of a whole-school behaviour framework (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4) (Core Content 3.4).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 13 Preplan and rehearse responses such as de-escalation as part of a whole-school behaviour framework (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.4) (Core Content 3.4).

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13

De-escalation (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4).

In this lecture, preservice teachers learn how to preplan and rehearse responses such as how to provide preventative low-level responses to de-escalate student behaviour, how to regulate their own responses to student behaviour so they can respond calmly, and different theoretical approaches to de-escalation (Brown, 2014; Education Queensland, 2007; Mitchell, 2017; Scott, 2016; Sexton et al., 2024). They are provided with examples of scripts to model respectful interactions designed to support de-escalation, and a reflection tool to consider function of student behaviour (Core Content 3.4.1, 3.4.3).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 13 De-escalation (APST 3.5, 4.1, 4.3, 4.4). In this lecture, preservice teachers learn how to preplan and rehearse responses such as how to provide preventative low-level responses to de-escalate student behaviour, how to regulate their own responses to student behaviour so they can respond calmly, and different theoretical approaches to de-escalation (Brown, 2014; Education Queensland, 2007; Mitchell, 2017; Scott, 2016; Sexton et al., 2024). They are provided with examples of scripts to model respectful interactions designed to support de-escalation, and a reflection tool to consider function of student behaviour (Core Content 3.4.1, 3.4.3).
